results.notes:
Spotted this one with the dark disc at 11AM on 9-2. Photographed it throughout the day, and throughout the following day (9-3). Weather conditions when I first spotted it, cloudy and warm. The mushroom received some direct sunlight late in the afternoon. Following morning the grass was wet with dew. Then the weather turned mostly sunny and hot. Mushroom shriveled up by day’s end 9-3, and the disc eventually faded somewhat. No rain throughout the period. Last photo shows shriveled cap with a fairly mono-color gray cap (still a bit darker near the center). I managed to collect a spore drop while the mushroom was in situ (see photo).

Spores broadly ellipsoid to subglobose, some ellipsoid (most observed were broadly ellipsoid). Some with one or more large oil drops, some with tiny oil drops, most also with “broken glass” contents (to use Igor’s characterization).
9-12(13) x 7-9(11). 1.1 < Q < 1.4(1.5). Scoped spores dropped on 4 different locations on the slide.

Unless something new comes to light, i think it makes sense to call all these gray Vaginatae that occur in two different locations on my property Amanita rooseveltensis. The variably dark disc and variability in size of fruit bodies appears to represent a morphological range that is likely dependent upon weather and/or availability of moisture. In each location the mushrooms are apparently associated with shagbark hickory (and possibly also oak in the one spot). The mushrooms begin fruiting in both locations as early as the first week of July and fruit continuously throughout the summer (when there’s sufficient rainfall). Spore dimensions consistently fall within the range 8-12 × 7-9 (with one notable exception last year where the spores were very large… possibly a different taxon).

notes_fields.Chemical_Reactions: The flesh bruises/stains reddish when the mushroom is cut in half. NH4OH and 5% KOH are negative on all parts of the mushroom. Iron Salt is dark blue green on the cap, stem, and flesh.
notes_fields.Macroscopic_Features:
Cap: 7.5 cm diameter with angular warts dotting the surface and a somewhat striated margin (about 5 mm of the cap edge with visible striations); the cap flesh is less than 1 mm at the edge widening to about 7 mm where the lamellae end next to the stipe.
Gills: Crowded, white, separate from stipe, 9-10 lamellae per cm, slightly serrated, ellipsoid in side view, 9 mm at widest point, 3 cm long.
Stipe: 12.5 cm long (including basal bulb), 8 mm at apex and 1.2 cm at base; whitish and fibrillose at the apex, pink red or brick red below remnant partial veil and scruffier in texture; remnant partial veil prominent and hanging from the stipe; basal bulb somewhat conical, approximately 2.5 cm wide and 2 cm long; stipe hollow, reddish in the hollow interior.

results.notes:
Code: Bot_388/2009_DSC5885

Habitat: Mixed, predominantly Fagus sylvatica forest, in shade, partly protected from direct rain by tree canopies, average precipitations ~3.000 mm/year, average temperature 3 -5 deg C, elevation 1.330 m (4.400 feet), alpine phytogeographical region.

Substratum: fallen, heavily rotted trunk of a deciduous tree, probably Fagus sylvatica.

Place: Bovec basin, Gozdec forest, above the road from Mt.Kanin cable car station B to the foot of Mt. Kopa, East Julian Alps, Posočje, Slovenia EC.

Comment: There was no microscopy done for this observation, hence the determination is unreliable. These pictures show immature sporocarps. Sporocysts have not yet opened, capillitium and spore mass are not yet visible. Also stalks are mostly not yet developed. This makes determination even more difficult. Nevertheless, the size and the shape of the oldest sporocarps and stalks with reddish tint points toward Hemitrichia clavata. But, it is possible that the pictures show other Hemitrichia or Trichia species like similar Trichia decipiens or Hemitrichia calyculata. Picture #10 shows eventually another species. On picture #18 one can see also two species of (probably) Ascomycetes – a larger jelly fungus and smaller black blobs (both lower left). A white ‘mycelium’ shown on the same picture (and others – upper left) probably belongs to another kind of fungus. Although Hemitrichia clavata has white plasmodium these fibers don’t seem to me to be its plasmodium.

Ref.:
(1) B. Ing, The Myxomycetes of Britain and Ireland,The Richmond Publ. Co.Ltd, (1999), p 127.
(2) S.L.Stephenson and H.Stempen, Myxomycetes, Timber Press Inc.(2000), p 124.
(x) M. Poulain, M. Meyer, J. Borronet, Les Myxomycetes, FMBDS (2011), Vol.1., p 371; Vol.2. p 130.
(3) S. Behrič, Raznolikost Pravih Sluzavk (Myxomycetes) v okolici Mengeša, (in Slovene) (True Slime Molds (Myxomycetes) Diversity in the Vicinity of Mengeš), Graduation thesis, University Studies, University in Ljubljana, Biotechnical Faculty, Biology department (2015), p 86.
(4) H. Neubert, W. Nowotny, K. Baumann – H. Marx, Die Myxomyceten Deutschlands und des angrenzenden Alpenraumes unter besonderen Berücksichtigung Österreichs, Vol.2.,Karlheinz Baumann Verlag, (1993, 1995, 2000), p 232.

Nikon D70 / Nikkor Micro 105mm/f2.8

results.notes:
Habitat: mulch of uncertain etiology
Cap: diameters to 66 mm, waxy dry, initially convex, uplifted margin at maturity, smooth, medium brown, soon lightening peripherally, hygrophanous
Gills: close, adnate with a decurrent tooth, pale but darkening to brown with persisting whitish, slightly serrate edges
Stipe: 50 mm long x 10 mm at apex and 6 mm at base. Whitish, white pruinose above the ring, brown fibrillose below it. Flesh white, solid, tough
Partial veil: membranous, felty, radial ridges on the upper surface, irregularly lumpy below. Separating from both the cap margin and stipe, persisting as a donut that falls down the stipe
Spore print: cigar brown
Odor & taste: Sharp odor of creosote. Taste mild

results.notes: What Ganoderma do. This broken Western hemlock stump and cut pieces laying further down a hill show perfectly the purpose of saprophytic fungi once a tree has become sick and or died. The mycelium will continue to break down all infected pieces of the fallen tree and continue to grow new fruiting bodies until eventually the cubicle rot will become usable soil for the forest floor, yet again. Will hope to monitor this process for the next two seasons to show progression and break down of the lignin rich substrate.

results.notes:
This is a fleshy Pleurotus that is not consistent with the only other Pleurotus species reported from Puerto Rico, Pleurotus djamor (previously reported as Pleurotus pulmonarius). One common lookalike would be Lentinus scleropus (=L.hirtus) which has a fuzzy cap margin and dark glandular dots at the base of the stipe, which is glabrous. Pleurotus djamor is generally smaller, thinner, and more fragile and tends to be attached occassionaly with a rudimentary stipe not reaching the measurements here.
Subsequent observations consistent with this one: observation 368987 observation 376336
Cap surface washed out, appearing glabrous. Striations on cap margin in some specimens. Gills of 3-4 lengths.
Growing from approximately 4in diameter fallen branch/log. Pileus growing laterally from an erect, excentric stipe.
Stipe diameter 6-18mm
Stipe length 14-24mm
Diam pileus 2.5-10cm
Smell, taste mild (not unpleasant)

results.notes:
Growing at the north entrance to Norman Mayer Building, under a broad-leafed tree that appears to be American holly. The dark smoky brown in young material gives way to a chestnut brown as the fruiting body matures. Stipe is smooth but appears scruffy and brown except at apex, where it is yellow. The ground is also yellow, though in the younger fruiting bodies the smoky gray-brown stipe decorations are dense enough to obscure the yellow considerably. Most stipes are slightly enlarged toward the base and the basal mycelium is dingy and only slightly paler than the brownish stipe.
Yellow pores are tiny and slightly decurrent. No staining on pore surface. Cap context stains blue slightly and slowly in older material. The younger fruiting bodies did not stain (to my knowledge).
Spore measurements and miscroscopy, courtesy of David Lewis: 5.5-7 × 4-5 microns; they are subglobose to short ellipsoid, and many have one oil droplet. The cuticle is a trichoderm and there is oleiferous hyphae in the cuticle. He writes further, “It appears to be a Phlebopus … Most boletes have long subfusiform spores while Phlebopus have globose to subglobose spores.”
From above, the irregularly shaped caps and the dark brown coloring suggest Boletinellus meruloides, which is what I thought I had found until I flipped these. Apparently Phlebopus and Boletinellus are phylogenetically close. The similar gestalts make sense.

—

results.notes:
Fruiting on a mature Cherry just off of North Street near our home in SouthEast Olympia, WA.

Laetiporus on Hardwoods in PNW=L. gilbertsonii
Laetiporus on Conifers in PNW=L. conifericola.
True L. sulphureus and L. cincinatus occur eastward/commonly in the Midwest.

Attached multiple images, including last years flush, now in what I call “dry wall” or “Styrofoam” status. Hoping for many more years of fresh fruiting from this same tree. Last years lot was delicious, mild and easily fried. Some collections of L. conifericola, in contrast, can occasionally be very bitter(like chewing aspirin) especially when harvested from Spruce substrates. All L. gilbertsonii and Midwest sulphureus have been mild, tender and akin truly to chicken(when young-as seen here).

Same substrate as last seasons observation here-linked below-
https://mushroomobserver.org/289361?q=ViNS

Stipe flesh: yellowish, bruised dark blue promptly.

Taste/Smell: did not taste. Smell is indistinct, maybe slightly musty but could be my imagination.

results.notes:
On coast live oak (Quercus agrifolia), smooth trunk bark of younger tree, in a maritime chaparral environment.

Thallus thin, white, continuous, K+Y. Apothecia common, not crowded, not flexuous, plane, up to about 0.5mm. Disk black, epruinose to lightly pruinose, with a thick white raised thalline margin concolorous with thallus. Epihymenium blue-black, POL-, pigments not soluble in K. Hymenium hyaline, hypothecium hyaline, K-, with fine white POL+ crystals that are K-, algal layer across base of apothecia discontinuous. Amphithecium with algae, and large K- crystals. Amphithecial cortex thick, composed of brown POL+ cells, extending down below the margin, basally thickened.

Spores simple, hyaline, broadly ellipsoid. Average size: 14.1×8.7 (n=8). On the large side for this species.

results.notes:
Code: Bot_837/2014_DSC4254

Habitat: mixed wood, Fagus sylvatica and Picea abies dominant trees; growing under Fagus; southeast oriented, moderately inclined mountain slope; shallow, skeletal soil layer; overgrown calcareous, colluvial sand, stone and scattered rocks; relatively dry and warm place; in shade; partly protected from direct rain by tree canopies; average precipitations ~ 3.000 mm/year, average temperature 7-9 deg C, elevation 620 m (2.030 feet), alpine phytogeographical region.

Substratum: soil.

Place: Lower Trenta valley, right bank of river Soča, between villages Soča and Trenta, between ‘Na Melu’, Trenta 2b and abandoned farm house ‘Strgulc’, Soča 47, East Julian Alps, Posočje, Slovenia EC.

Comments: Taxonomical history of Lactarius luridus is very complicated (Ref.2. – see Systematik). Species names luridus, uvidus, acris, violascens have been used differently by different authors. I rely on Basso (1999) Ref.3 and IF. She keeps in the section Uvidi (having violet milk) six species. The fungi photographed correspond the closest to the description of Lactarius luridus although the description of its hut doesn’t fit very well. Hut of Lactarius luridus is according to most sources ‘more or less’ zonate, while the mushrooms found were not. Exceptionally, the picture published in Breitenbach (2005) Ref.6. shows two pilei, which are also not zonate. Other options of determination seem less appropriate: L. violascens is distinctly, dark zonate and has narrower spores, L. cistophilus is a Mediterranean species, L. pseudouvidus and L. robertianus are Arctic – Alpine elevations species. Although L. uvidus has azonate pileus like this find, it grows under Betula, Salix, and sometimes under Picea abies, has narrower spores (but not according to Ref.4) and prefers moist habitats. Hence Lactarius luridus seems the best option for this find.

Two pilei were found about 20 m apart in the same habitat; pilei 6-7 cm in diameter; cutis viscid; stipe dry, 5 cm tall and 1.3 cm in diameter, hollow; gills bruise gray-violet when cut or damaged; milk whitish-pale-yellow, with time and in contact with gills becoming pale violet; trama when cut slowly darkens gray-violet; SP whitish-beige, oac857.

Nikon D700/Nikkor Micro 105mm/f2.8

results.notes:
Found in Zone 48 under red and white pine, Balsam fir, sugar maple, and paper birch, close to a Leccinum mushroom. There were several of the Amanitas of which I photographed three.

This is one of at least two muscarioid species from sect. Amanita that show up here: this one small, fragile, yellow with white warts, found in dense forest in deep shade; the other huge and robust, orange before being faded by the sun but can fade to yellow or even whitish, with whitish to dingy off-white warts, found near the fringes of pine woods such as at the edges of Zones 19 and 2. The latter matches what’s generally called Amanita muscaria var. guessowii, whereas this species is much smaller and seems to prefer a somewhat different habitat.
results.location_name: Forest near Elgin St., Pembroke, Ontario, Canada

results.notes: Pale, but with a yellow-greenish tinge, stronger in the center, and distinctly yellow gills. results.notes: Found in Zone 38 under red and white pine, sugar maple, paper birch, Balsam fir, jack pine, and quaking aspen. Resembles the Russulas found in the same zone, but is something else: these mushrooms have plentiful short gills, while the Russulas had none as is common in that genus. This was also less fragile than a typical member of Russulales and did not produce latex when damaged, so I have doubts about it being in Russulales at all.

results.notes:
This all-white Amanita was solitary, barely out of the button stage, and found in Zone 38 beneath red, white, and jack pine, sugar maple, paper birch, and Balsam fir. Can’t 100% rule out aspens nearby.

The wart rings on the bulb may place this in the muscaria group, but previously the only all-white ones I’ve seen have been large muscaria var. guessowii that had been sun-bleached to hell and gone. This was tiny, in a highly shady area, and is thus almost certainly naturally this pale and of a different species.

I didn’t notice a smell, but the paleness means I’m not willing to rule out sect. Lepidella at this point. If so it would be the first I’d seen though. If it isn’t one of those it’s probably in sect. Amanita with the fly agarics.

results.notes: A fruiting body(about 70ft. up the Douglas fir substrate) that I have monitored for many, many years. Still alive and producing new annual growth layers in the habitual downward, beehive appearing fashion(narrowing and lengthening w/each passing season). Took fellow myconut Paul Hill and fellow Mycologist Django Grootmeyers to this old friend during early Spring in 2016 to acquaint them with one of my favorite, sacred stomping grounds here. Hoping this(and the two other Agarikon infected Douglas firs I know, love and have monitored) at the park continue to grow for many more years to come.

results.notes:
Pileus: 100 × 66 mm, broadly convex to pulvinate, upturned brittle margin, floccose to roughly 1/3 in from margin, several pits near center, somewhat radially streaked, buff/beige with lighter center and margin.

Context: 5 mm thick, eburneous, does not stain.

Lamellae: emarginate, pale buff/beige, close, broad, undulate to subserrulate.

Stipe: 93 × 14 mm, equal, pale buff/beige, narrowly hollow, clavate base.

Spore Print: white.

Spores: 5 – 7.5 × 5-6 µm, amygdaliform, hyaline, inamyloid.

Habitat: terrestrial under mixed hardwoods and conifers (primarily oaks, maple & hemlock).

notes_fields.Comments:
Mature spores were difficult to come by. I could find practically none floating out in the medium. Those I felt comfortable measuring gave me the following:

(6.6) 7.8 – 9.3 (11.2) × (1.9) 2.4 – 2.9 (3.1) µm
Q = (2.7) 2.75 – 3.6 (4.3) ; N = 10
Me = 8.5 × 2.6 µm ; Qe = 3.4

If I had to guess, I would assume these are 1-, max 2-septate at maturity. Asci IKI+. Also note apically forked paraphyses.
